addresses.name: Bridger
addresses.description: Bridger gateway that can swap assets to 'L2 final assets' before bridging them to the L2.

addresses.name: ValidatorUtils
addresses.description: This contract implements view only utilities for validators.

addresses.name: OneStepProver0
addresses.description: One of the modular contracts used for the last step of a fraud proof, which is simulated inside a WASM virtual machine.

addresses.name: RollupProxy
addresses.description: Central contract for the project's configuration like its execution logic hash (`wasmModuleRoot`) and addresses of the other system contracts. Entry point for Proposers creating new Rollup Nodes (state commitments) and Challengers submitting fraud proofs (In the Orbit stack, these two roles are both held by the Validators).

addresses.name: RollupEventInbox
addresses.description: Helper contract sending configuration data over the bridge during the systems initialization.

addresses.name: OneStepProverHostIo
addresses.description: One of the modular contracts used for the last step of a fraud proof, which is simulated inside a WASM virtual machine.

addresses.name: UpgradeExecutor
addresses.description:
* Can act on behalf of ProxyAdmin.
* Can be used to configure RollupProxy  - Pause and unpause and set important roles and parameters in the system contracts.
* Can be used to upgrade implementation of RollupProxy.
* Central contract defining the access control permissions for upgrading the system contract implementations.

addresses.name: ChallengeManager
addresses.description: Contract that allows challenging state roots. Can be called through the RollupProxy by Validators or the UpgradeExecutor.

addresses.name: Outbox
addresses.description: Facilitates L2 to L1 contract calls: Messages initiated from L2 (for example withdrawal messages) eventually resolve in execution on L1.

addresses.name: ProxyAdmin
addresses.description: Can be used to upgrade implementation of RollupEventInbox, UpgradeExecutor, ChallengeManager, Outbox, L1ERC20Gateway, Bridge, Inbox, L1GatewayRouter, SequencerInbox.

addresses.name: OneStepProverMemory
addresses.description: One of the modular contracts used for the last step of a fraud proof, which is simulated inside a WASM virtual machine.

addresses.name: L1ERC20Gateway
addresses.description: Escrows deposited ERC-20 assets for the canonical Bridge. Upon depositing, a generic token representation will be minted at the destination. Withdrawals are initiated by the Outbox contract.

addresses.name: Bridge
addresses.description: Escrow contract for the project's gas token (Can be different from ETH). Keeps a list of allowed Inboxes and Outboxes for canonical bridge messaging.

addresses.name: OneStepProverMath
addresses.description: One of the modular contracts used for the last step of a fraud proof, which is simulated inside a WASM virtual machine.

addresses.name: Inbox
addresses.description: Facilitates sending L1 to L2 messages like depositing ETH, but does not escrow funds.

addresses.name: L1GatewayRouter
addresses.description: This routing contract maps tokens to the correct escrow (gateway) to be then bridged with canonical messaging.

addresses.name: OneStepProofEntry
addresses.description: One of the modular contracts used for the last step of a fraud proof, which is simulated inside a WASM virtual machine.

addresses.name: SequencerInbox
addresses.description: A sequencer (registered in this contract) can submit transaction batches or commitments here.

risks.text: a contract receives a malicious code upgrade. There is no delay on code upgrades.

dataAvailability.name: All data required for proofs is published on chain
dataAvailability.description: All the data that is used to construct the system state is published on chain in the form of cheap blobs or calldata. This ensures that it will be available for enough time.

references.text: Sequencing followed by deterministic execution - Arbitrum documentation
SequencerInbox.sol - Etherscan source code, addSequencerL2BatchFromOrigin function

operator.name: The system has a centralized sequencer
operator.description: While forcing transaction is open to anyone the system employs a privileged sequencer that has priority for submitting transaction batches and ordering transactions.

risks.text: the operator exploits their centralized position and frontruns user transactions.

forceTransactions.name: Users can force any transaction
forceTransactions.description: Because the state of the system is based on transactions submitted on the underlying host chain and anyone can submit their transactions there it allows the users to circumvent censorship by interacting with the smart contract on the host chain directly. After a delay of 1d in which a Sequencer has failed to include a transaction that was directly posted to the smart contract, it can be forcefully included by anyone on the host chain, which finalizes its ordering.

references.text: SequencerInbox.sol - Etherscan source code, forceInclusion function
Sequencer Isn’t Doing Its Job - Arbitrum documentation

exitMechanisms.name: Regular exit
exitMechanisms.description: The user initiates the withdrawal by submitting a regular transaction on this chain. When the block containing that transaction is finalized the funds become available for withdrawal on L1. The process of block finalization usually takes several days to complete. Finally the user submits an L1 transaction to claim the funds. This transaction requires a merkle proof.

references.text: L2 to L1 Messages - Arbitrum documentation

exitMechanisms.name: Tradeable Bridge Exit
exitMechanisms.description: When a user initiates a regular withdrawal a third party verifying the chain can offer to buy this withdrawal by paying the user on L1. The user will get the funds immediately, however the third party has to wait for the block to be finalized. This is implemented as a first party functionality inside Arbitrum's token bridge.

exitMechanisms.name: Autonomous exit
exitMechanisms.description: Users can (eventually) exit the system by pushing the transaction on L1 and providing the corresponding state root. The only way to prevent such withdrawal is via an upgrade.

otherConsiderations.name: Enforced smart wallets and KYC
otherConsiderations.description:
The Kinto L2 node is a fork of Arbitrum's geth implementation with notable changes to the state transition function. 
      A valid state transition in Kinto [disallows all contract calls by EOAs](https://github.com/KintoXYZ/kinto-go-ethereum/blob/7aba9b812a82d9339d29a2345946c3d7030a0377/core/kinto_hardfork_7.go#L58) and new contract creation, unless specifically whitelisted. 
      The current whitelist is sourced directly from the KintoAppRegistry smart contract on Kinto L2, and can be modified by its Owner without delay. 
      This setup effectively enforces smart wallet use because the auxiliary contracts of the standard KintoWallet smart wallet (like the EntryPoint and the KintoWalletFactory) are whitelisted.
        
      The KYC validation is part of the KintoWallet signature verification. Since all users must use the same implementation of this smart wallet, all user transactions on Kinto check for an up-to-date KYC flag, and are dropped in case the check fails.

risks.text: a KYC provider changes the users' KYC status.

permissions.name: Sequencer
permissions.description: Can submit transaction batches or commitments to the SequencerInbox contract on the host chain.

permissions.name: Validator/Proposer
permissions.description: Can propose new state roots (called nodes) and challenge state roots on the host chain.

permissions.name: Kinto SecurityCouncil
permissions.description:
* A Gnosis Safe with 6 / 8 threshold. 
* Can act on behalf of UpgradeExecutor.
* Can change the configuration of RollupProxy (acting via UpgradeExecutor) - Pause and unpause and set important roles and parameters in the system contracts.
* Can upgrade the implementation of RollupProxy (acting via UpgradeExecutor).
* Can upgrade the implementation of RollupEventInbox, UpgradeExecutor, ChallengeManager, Outbox, L1ERC20Gateway, Bridge, Inbox, L1GatewayRouter, SequencerInbox (acting via ProxyAdmin, UpgradeExecutor).

permissions.name: BridgerOwnerMultisig
permissions.description:
* A Gnosis Safe with 3 / 5 threshold. 
* Can upgrade the implementation of Bridger.

permissions.name: TurnkeyMultisig
permissions.description:
* A Gnosis Safe with 1 / 5 threshold. 
* Member of Kinto SecurityCouncil.

permissions.name: Ankr EOA
permissions.description: A Validator  - Can propose new state roots (called nodes) and challenge state roots on the host chain.

permissions.name: Hypernative EOA 2
permissions.description: A Validator  - Can propose new state roots (called nodes) and challenge state roots on the host chain.

permissions.name: Caldera EOA 2
permissions.description: A Validator  - Can propose new state roots (called nodes) and challenge state roots on the host chain.

permissions.name: Mamori Labs EOA 3
permissions.description: A Validator  - Can propose new state roots (called nodes) and challenge state roots on the host chain.

permissions.name: EOA 1
permissions.description: A Sequencer  - Can submit transaction batches or commitments to the SequencerInbox contract on the host chain.

permissions.name: Venn EOA 2
permissions.description: A Validator  - Can propose new state roots (called nodes) and challenge state roots on the host chain.

stateValidation.description: Updates to the system state can be proposed and challenged by a set of whitelisted validators. If a state root passes the challenge period, it is optimistically considered correct and made actionable for withdrawals.

categories.title: State root proposals
categories.description: Whitelisted validators propose state roots as children of a previous state root. A state root can have multiple conflicting children. This structure forms a graph, and therefore, in the contracts, state roots are referred to as nodes. Each proposal requires a stake, currently set to 0.1 ETH, that can be slashed if the proposal is proven incorrect via a fraud proof. Stakes can be moved from one node to one of its children, either by calling `stakeOnExistingNode` or `stakeOnNewNode`. New nodes cannot be created faster than the minimum assertion period by the same validator, currently set to 15m. The oldest unconfirmed node can be confirmed if the challenge period has passed and there are no siblings, and rejected if the parent is not a confirmed node or if the challenge period has passed and no one is staked on it.

risks.text: none of the whitelisted verifiers checks the published state. Fraud proofs assume at least one honest and able validator.

references.text: How is fraud proven - Arbitrum documentation FAQ

categories.title: Challenges
categories.description: A challenge can be started between two siblings, i.e. two different state roots that share the same parent, by calling the `startChallenge` function. Validators cannot be in more than one challenge at the same time, meaning that the protocol operates with [partial concurrency](https://medium.com/l2beat/fraud-proof-wars-b0cb4d0f452a). Since each challenge lasts 6d 8h, this implies that the protocol can be subject to [delay attacks](https://medium.com/offchainlabs/solutions-to-delay-attacks-on-rollups-434f9d05a07a), where a malicious actor can delay withdrawals as long as they are willing to pay the cost of losing their stakes. If the protocol is delayed attacked, the new stake requirement increases exponentially for each challenge period of delay. Challenges are played via a bisection game, where asserter and challenger play together to find the first instruction of disagreement. Such instruction is then executed onchain in the WASM OneStepProver contract to determine the winner, who then gets half of the stake of the loser. As said before, a state root is rejected only when no one left is staked on it. The protocol does not enforces valid bisections, meaning that actors can propose correct initial claim and then provide incorrect midpoints.

milestones.name: Security Council Governance
milestones.description: Kinto gives the ownership of all L1 system contracts to a Security Council that is properly set up.

milestones.name: First ever Challenge on mainnet
milestones.description: The first correctly resolved fault proof challenge of a mainnet Orbit stack rollup.

milestones.name: Mainnet full launch
milestones.description: Engen mining is completed and locked funds are bridged to the Kinto L2.

milestones.name: Kinto Mainnet Genesis
milestones.description: Kinto mainnet is launched. Deposits by users are disabled.

display.warning: Fraud proof system is fully deployed but is not yet permissionless as it requires Validators to be whitelisted.
display.name: Kinto
display.description: Kinto is an Orbit stack L2 with account abstraction and KYC enabled for all users, supporting both modern financial institutions and decentralized protocols.

warnings.stateUpdates: Please note, for Optimistic rollups the state is not finalized until the challenge period passes.

liveness.explanation: Kinto is an Optimistic Rollup that posts transaction data to the L1. For a transaction to be considered final, it has to be posted to the L1. Forced txs can be delayed up to 1d. The state root gets finalized 6d 8h after it has been posted.

requirements: Upgrades executed by actors with more centralized control than a Security Council provide less than 7d for users to exit if the permissioned operator is down or censoring.

requirements.description: The project calls itself a rollup.
State roots are posted to Ethereum L1.
Inputs for the state transition function are posted to Ethereum L1.

A source-available node exists that can recreate the state from Ethereum L1 data. Please note that the L2BEAT team has not verified the validity of the node source code. [View code](https://docs.kinto.xyz/kinto-the-safe-l2/building-on-kinto/running-kinto-nodes)
A complete and functional proof system is deployed.
There are at least 5 external actors who can submit fraud proofs.
Users are able to exit without the help of the permissioned operators.
Upgrades executed by actors with more centralized control than a Security Council provide less than 7d for users to exit if the permissioned operator is down or censoring.
The Security Council is properly set up [(List of members)](https://docs.kinto.xyz/kinto-the-safe-l2/security-kyc-aml/security-council).
Fraud proof submission is open only to whitelisted actors.
Upgrades unrelated to onchain provable bugs provide less than 30d to exit.
The Security Council's actions are not confined to onchain provable bugs.

layer.description: The data is posted to Ethereum as calldata or blobs.

bridge.description: The validating bridge has access to all the data, as it is posted onchain.

stateValidation.description: Fraud proofs allow 5 WHITELISTED actors watching the chain to prove that the state is incorrect. Interactive proofs (INT) require multiple transactions over time to resolve. There is a 6d 8h challenge period.

dataAvailability.description: All of the data needed for proof construction is published on Ethereum L1.

exitWindow.description: There is no window for users to exit in case of an unwanted regular upgrade since contracts are instantly upgradable.

sequencerFailure.description: In the event of a sequencer failure, users can force transactions to be included in the project's chain by sending them to L1. There is a 1d delay on this operation.

proposerFailure.description: Anyone can become a Proposer after 12d 17h of inactivity from the currently whitelisted Proposers.

contract.description: Contract managing Inboxes and Outboxes. It escrows ETH sent to L2.
Bridger gateway that can swap assets to 'L2 final assets' before bridging them to the L2.

function addSequencerL2Batch(uint256 sequenceNumber,bytes calldata data,uint256 afterDelayedMessagesRead,address gasRefunder,uint256 prevMessageCount,uint256 newMessageCount)
function addSequencerL2Batch(uint256 sequenceNumber,bytes calldata data,uint256 afterDelayedMessagesRead,address gasRefunder,uint256 prevMessageCount,uint256 newMessageCount)
function addSequencerL2BatchFromOrigin(uint256 sequenceNumber,bytes data,uint256 afterDelayedMessagesRead,address gasRefunder,uint256 prevMessageCount,uint256 newMessageCount)
